member.name: T:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.CrossSectionPointUtilities
member.summary: A number of algorithms, that are not currently used, and therefor placed here

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.CrossSectionPointUtilities.GetResistance(DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSBaseRaw,DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.ICrossSectionPoint,DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.CrossSectionPointList)
member.summary: Returns resistance factor, accounting for the owning cross section's ResistanceDistribution (if there is an owning cross section, otherwise return the distributed value). The EUM unit and type depend on the cross section's ResistanceFormulation!. Several additional special issues, see remarks!
member.remarks: For Uniform or Zones, the resistance factor is dependent also on markers' positions within the entire cross section, so it must be computed on the fly. In either case, if left and right levee bank markers (1 and 3) are not both defined or lie on the same point, the default value of 1.0 is returned. Another thing: The leftmost resistance is meaningless for the engine. This code replaces the XSOpen.UpdateResistanceXXX methods in the MZ code. Those were more efficient, but there was a risk of the Point returning a wrong value if the Update method hadn't been called before for the entire cross section. The most inefficient part, for Zones resistance distribution, is hardly ever used in M11.

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.CrossSectionPointUtilities.GetIntermediatePoint(DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSBase,DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.CrossSectionPointList,DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.ICrossSectionPoint,DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.ICrossSectionPoint,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a point within this cross section, if need be by interpolating neighbors. Any interpolated point will have (1) Interpolated = true; (2) Owner = null; (3) Zone = that of the right neighbor (following convention); (4) Z and Resistance from linear interpolation relative to transversalRelativeDistance. If there are multiple points at that position ("vertical wall"), return their average.
member.param: List that the left and right points belong to
reference point on the left. OK if null, then the interpolation will return a Clone of the right point (if that is non-null)
reference point on the left. OK if null, then the interpolation will return a Clone of the left point (if that is non-null)
If false, and if there is a point already on the Owner of this cross section point position, return a Clone of that. If true, interpolate always.
member.returns: interpolated point

member.name: T:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSCircularPreprocessed
member.summary:
Closed Circular Cross Section with preprocessed data. There are several different types of circular cross sections: - Circular. - Egg-shaped circular. - O-shaped circular.
For the O-shaped cross section the is 9/8*diameter
The preprocessed data contains a slot up to a height of 1.5 times the diameter. Hence, the does not equal plus the diameter/height.
member.remarks:
The (pre)processed data are scaled with the diameter, i.e., the are storage widths for a circular cross section with diameter 1.
Do not update in the processed data, since that will change the processed data for all cross sections of this type.

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSCircularPreprocessed.GetNaturalDepthBase(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
Same results as , when manning is uniform (no depth dependence). Otherwise results will differ slightly.
This version is more "correct", since calculate the max conveyance based on MAR23 and limits the value of MAR23, while the does it only on AR23. Hence results will differ when manning varies with depth.
However, with the table it is possible to do binary search (currently linear search)

member.name: T:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSBase
member.summary:
Base class for crossSections. Holds processed data.
The most common case is that is zero, meaning that the are depth based. However, this is not a requirement.
Can hold equidistant as well as non-equidistant processed data, . In case of equidistant, the processed levels always start at zero, i.e., the is always zero (depth based).

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSBase.ConvertRelativeResistanceMultiZones(System.Double[],System.Double[],DHI.Mike1D.Generic.ResistanceFormulation)
member.summary:
Converts the according to a multizone set of absolute resistance values.
Each input factor is applied between each level seperator, the first factor from -infinity to the first level, the second factor from the first level to the second level, and the last factor from the last level to infinity, i.e., the levelSeperators defines where one factor takes over from the previous.
The factors array must be one longer than the levelSeperators array.
The relative resistance factor is taken into account also.
Results are stored in the and those are used in the calculation.
member.param: The resistance formulation that the factors refer to
member.remarks: Average factors are applied for depths that fall exactly on one of the levelseperators

member.summary:
Multiplies or divides the factors with the .
Each input factor is applied between each level seperator, the first factor from -infinity to the first level, the second factor from the first level to the second level, and the last factor from the last level to infinity, i.e., the depthSeperators defines where one factor takes over from the previous.
The factors array must be one longer than the depthSeperators array.
Results are stored in the and those are used in the calculation.
member.param: Factors to multiply the resistance with

member.remarks: Average factors are applied for levels that fall exactly on one of the levelseperators

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSBase.GenerateCriticalDischarges(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Generate the _processedCriticalDisharge array, on each level of processed data adding sqrt(g*A^3/b)
member.param: True of the critical discharges are created so they are always increasing.

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSBase.GetCriticalDischarge(System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the Critical discharge for a given water level The critical discharge is the discharge where the flow changes from supercritical to subcritical flow.
member.remarks:
Based on Equation (4.13) p. 150 in "Hydraulik", F.A. Engelund and Fl. Bo Pedersen, 1978 The alpha (see Equation (2.23) p. 80) is set to 1 (as on p. 156, p. 167 ?) Alpha is the "hastigheds-fordelings-coefficient" - velocity-distribution-coefficient.
Qcrit = Sqrt(g*A^3/b) = Sqrt(g*A/b)*A = Sqrt(g*D)*A
where D=A/b is the average depth.

member.name: T:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.InterpolateXSProcessed
member.summary: Class that creates a new cross section as an interpolation in processed data between two neighbouring cross sections.

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.InterpolateXSProcessed.Interpolate(DHI.Mike1D.Generic.ILocation,DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.ICrossSection,DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.ICrossSection,DHI.Mike1D.Generic.Diagnostics)
member.summary:
Create a new ICrossSection that is interpolated from the cross sections before and after the newLocation, positioned at the newLocation.
It returns a cross section based on a that contains only processed data. I.e., it only interpolates processed data.
member.param: New location for interpolated cross section
Diagnostics instance for reporting errors. Can be null.
member.returns: Interpolated cross section
member.remarks:
The interpolation works as follows: The new cross section get the maximume number of levels of the two up-and down-stream cross sections. From the top (!) each level is matched and interpolated linearly in chainage
levels_new[end-i] = (1-ratio) * level_before[end-i] + ratio * level_after[end-i];
where end indicates the top level index of each. If one index gets below 0, the bottom level value is used instead.
This is a quite primitive interpolation, not always giving the desired results. Especially: - Storage widths and areas does not match very well anymore, therefor geometric areas are recalculated by integrating up widths. - Flow areas are not recalculated, and does therefor not match storage widhts. This is in order to get backward compatible results (since M11 does it this way).

member.name: T:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.CrossSectionData
member.summary:
A class representing a collection of cross sections, spanning multiple reaches.
The collection orders the cross sections in two ways: If a reach only has one global cross-section, it is indexed by reachID and topoID. Other cross sections which have a location including a chainage, are ordered by locationID (reachID), topoID and chainage.
If a cross section gets its location updated after insertion into the collection, it needs to be removed and reinserted into the collection in order to be indexed correctly.
Events are not supported for COM interop, even though they appear in the type lib.
All physical quantities are in SI units.

member.summary: Create a runtime Diagnostics instance. This is called from the initializer which contains the cross section data since there is no initializer here (CrossSectionData is created during load, not initialization).

member.summary:
Find a cross section based on the location and topoID. If no cross section is found (chainage within Constants.LOCATION_EQUAL_TOLERANCE), null is returned.
If the reach defined in the location has a global cross section, the global cross section is returned. TODO: Consider returning null instead
This is meant for editing the cross sections, use Get to always get a cross section at a location.
member.param: Location at which to look for a cross section
member.returns: A cross section at the location. null if not found

member.summary:

This is meant for editing the cross sections, use Get to always get a cross section at a location.
member.param: Location at which to look for a cross section
member.returns: A cross section at the location. null if not found

member.summary:
Find and remove a cross section based on the location and topoID. If no cross section is found (chainage within Constants.LOCATION_EQUAL_TOLERANCE), false is returned.
If the reach defined in the location has a global cross section, the global cross section is removed. TODO: Consider doing nothing
member.param: Location at which to look for a cross section to remove
member.returns: True if a cross section was removed, false otherwise
member.remarks: If first tries to remove the crosssection with the exact chainage value. If not found, it removes the first one with a chainage value within Constants.LOCATION_EQUAL_TOLERANCE

member.summary:
Gets the cross-sections on locations inside span.
If is true, then cross sections must be strictly inside span (cross sections must be inside span).
If is false, then cross sections on the end of the span will be included (within tolerance of ).
Uses StrictContains in the locationSpan to match. If there is a global cross section for this reachID, then an array of length 0 is returned.

Flag specifying whether cross sections at the end of the location span should be included or not.
member.returns: A list of CrossSections within LocationSpan

member.name: T:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.FlowResistance
member.summary:
Holds information about cross section resistance.
It contains information on the formulation used, , and also the resistance values unless they are tabulated.
If resistance values are tabulated, == , they should be looked up in the processed data of the cross sections.
If the == the following formula is used:
r(d,h) = r_b + (r_t - r_b) * Math.Pow(d / h, c);
with depth derivative
r'(d,h) = (c/h)(r_t - r_b) * Math.Pow(d / h, c-1);
where r_b is r_t is and c is
During simulation the engine works on Mannings M or Chezy, and converts the other resistance formulations to one of those. The converted/modified values and formulations are stored in the .
member.remarks: Remember to set as well the resistance value as the type.

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.FlowResistance.ConvertToStandardResistances(DHI.Mike1D.Generic.ResistanceFormulation,DHI.Mike1D.Generic.ResistanceFormulation@,System.Double[],System.Double[]@,System.Double[])
member.summary:
Convert from the current formulation to the new/standard formulation.
To make inplace conversion, give the resistance array to both of the currentResistances and newResistances arguments.
Not all type of conversions are supported. Currently only : - Mannings n is converted to Mannings M

member.name: P:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.ProcessingLevelsSpecs.UserDefLevels
member.summary:
the levels for user-defined processing (absolute elevations in [m]!), or null if none. Must be strictly monotonically increasing. Apart from these, the relative min and max levels, plus the datum, from the raw data will also be part of the processed levels. NOTE: if you set an individual value within the array, you must re-process the hydraulic data.
Levels are relative to raw data, and must not include any datum offset

member.summary: Gets the Natural depth for a given discharge [m3/s] and slope [dimensionless] The natural depth is the depth where the flow resistance and velocity balances, i.e., the Manning formula is fullfilled: Q = M*A*R^(2/3)*sqrt(I)

member.name: T:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSPolygonProcessedTopSlotter
member.summary:
Class that puts a processed top slot on an XSPolygon, by adding 50 (default) extra layers on top of the existing processed data. The extra layers follows an exponentially decreasing width profile. The area of the cross section in the slot is kept constant (i.e. when water level is increasing, water dissapears, and when water decreases again, the water reappears)
It stores the original processed data and is capable of reverting when the calculation has finished.

member.name: F:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSPolygonProcessedTopSlotter.NumberOfSlotLevels
member.summary: Number of levels to add above existing processed data. Default: 50

member.name: F:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSPolygonProcessedTopSlotter.HeightFraction
member.summary: Height of the added top slot, as a fraction of the original cross section height. Default: 1.0

member.name: F:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSPolygonProcessedTopSlotter.TopWidthFraction
member.summary: The fraction of the MaxWidth that is to be used as top width (width at infinity level) in the slot. Default 0.01.
member.remarks: The epspar in the MU Delphi code

member.name: F:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSPolygonProcessedTopSlotter.InterfaceHeightFraction
member.summary: The fraction of the MaxWidth that is to be used as height of the top slot interface (top part of original cross section that is modified to match the slot). Default 0.05.
member.remarks: Matching the fpar*epspar in the MU Delphi code

member.name: F:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSPolygonProcessedTopSlotter.SlotConveyanceFactor
member.summary: A factor correcting the hydraulic radius such that the conveyance at the top of the slot is this factor larger than the conveyance at the top of the original cross section.

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSPolygonProcessedTopSlotter.Revert
member.summary: Revert the processed data in the XSPolygon to the original data

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSPolygonProcessedTopSlotter.Process
member.summary: Process the XSPolygon

member.name: M:DHI.Mike1D.CrossSectionModule.XSPolygonProcessedTopSlotter.CalculateExpDecreasingWidth(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate width based on a decreasing exponential formulation
member.param: Angle from level axis to width curve at start-level (called tanv0 in MU)
Width at infinity level of slot
Level to calculate width for. Must be larger than slot start level
member.returns: Width at given level
member.remarks: Compared to the MU implementation of this function, to get the same result, call this with CalculateExpDecreasingWidth(2*slope, ...)
